title: #PrayForLondon: Don’t judge those who share hashtags and the Union Jack in aftermath of Westminster terror attack
text:
Messages poured out after the attack (Picture: Metro.co.uk) Yesterday was awful – that’s an understatement. 
A terror attack right on our doorstep and three people dead – PC Keith Palmer , mother-of-two Aysha Frade , and the assailant .
Fundraiser started for family of PC Keith Palmer murdered in London terror attack Another 29 were injured and needed hospital treatment while seven others remain critically injured.
Most of us watched the tragic events at Westminster unfold from the safety of our homes or offices.
It is hard to tear yourself away from television screens or the running commentary on news websites and Twitter, and it’s hard to know what to do.
But you feel you must do something.
And for many, that means turning to social media to post our condolences or support using hashtags like #PrayForLondon and #WeStandTogether.
This is London… #PROUD #PrayForLondon #WeStandTogether #WestminsterAttack pic.twitter.com/sCx5Exv75i 
— Kishan Devani FRSA (@Kishan_Devani) March 23, 2017 

People will change their profile pictures to Union Jack flags or post pictures of candles asking for prayers.
However, alongside these well wishes comes a sort of sneering response from people wishing to point out that praying and the like does nothing to resolve these tragedies.
Boris Johnson vows terror attacker 'will not succeed' in Churchillian speech ‘What good does praying do?’ they ask.
Almost always, these people neglect to tell us how we can practically help in situations like this.
In the immediate aftermath, there is very little most of us can do.
These people have missed the entire point of sharing these statements.
It is not that people expect these complex issues to immediately be resolved.
Not one person expects that adding a Facebook filter of a flag to their profile picture will irradiate worldwide terrorism.
No one believes that these terrorist organisations will rethink their ideologies because Sharon in Newcastle has shared a picture of the Palace of Westminster on Instagram with the hashtag #PrayForLondon and a sad face emoji.
A police officer places flowers and a photo of PC Keith Palmer on Whitehall near the Houses of Parliament in London (Picture: Dominic Lipinski/PA Wire) Nor the fact that. because Tom from Tunbridge Wells added a Union Jack flag to his Facebook profile picture of him and the boys in Maga, it will give them pause for thought.
Nobody thinks this will happen. Not one person.
But what it does do is show solidarity with each other and, importantly, with those who have suffered.
More: UK MPs praise children locked in Parliament during London attack

It gives others a moment to reflect as they scroll through news feeds.
It is a way of showing camaraderie and letting those who wish to disturb the peace in the UK and beyond know that we are not scared, that we will carry on and that we will live our lives without fear.
The use of these hashtags and pictures on social media is the modern-day equivalent of the candlelight vigil.
Yes, practically they are not very helpful.
Landmarks lit up in solidarity with London after terror attack (Picture: Reuters) But to some, it shows strength in numbers and that despite the numerous social, cultural, political and religious differences in the UK, we are here for one another.
It shows that we won’t kowtow to terrorists and that we are grateful to the police, ambulance and firefighters – those who run towards danger when most of us would runaway.
Westminster Bridge re-opens less than 24 hours after terror attack We are proud of our country.
It’s to give comfort to those who feel anxious after these attacks, letting them know that they are not alone – we all feel like that but we all must carry on because to live in fear is to let them win.
It may seem like a futile and simplistic response to some people but to others, it can help them feel comforted in uncertain times.
If you don’t want to do it, don’t do it. Nobody will judge.
But don’t judge those who do – there is already enough hatred, pessimism and negativity in the world.
